title: Call and Healing
shortSummary: Luke chapter 5 presents Jesus calling His first disciples through a miraculous catch of fish, demonstrating His divine authority and power. It also records Jesus healing a leper and a paralytic, emphasizing His authority to forgive sins and His mission to call sinners to repentance.
timeline: c. AD 27-28 - Early ministry of Jesus in Galilee

keyCharacters.name: Simon Peter
keyCharacters.description: A fisherman called by Jesus to be a disciple; he witnesses the miraculous catch of fish and responds with humility and faith.

keyCharacters.name: James and John
keyCharacters.description: Sons of Zebedee and partners with Simon Peter; they are also called by Jesus to follow Him and become fishers of men.

keyCharacters.name: Levi (Matthew)
keyCharacters.description: A tax collector called by Jesus to follow Him, who responds immediately and hosts a feast for Jesus and His disciples.

keyCharacters.name: The Paralytic Man
keyCharacters.description: A man healed by Jesus after being lowered through a roof, illustrating Jesus' authority to forgive sins and heal.

definitions.definition: A chronic infectious disease causing skin lesions and nerve damage, considered ceremonially unclean in Jewish law.
A tax collector, often despised by Jews for collaborating with Roman authorities and perceived as sinners.
A large catch of fish, often used metaphorically in the New Testament for gathering people into God's kingdom.
A Messianic title Jesus frequently used for Himself, emphasizing both His humanity and divine authority.

outline.heading: The Miraculous Catch of Fish and Calling of Disciples
outline.description: Jesus teaches from Simon Peter’s boat and instructs him to cast nets into deep water, resulting in a miraculous catch. This event leads to Peter’s recognition of Jesus’ holiness and the calling of Peter, James, and John to follow Him as fishers of men.

outline.heading: Healing of a Man with Leprosy
outline.description: Jesus heals a man full of leprosy by touching him, demonstrating His compassion and power to cleanse both physically and spiritually, while instructing the man to follow Mosaic law as a testimony.

outline.heading: Forgiveness and Healing of the Paralytic
outline.description: Jesus forgives the sins of a paralytic brought by friends, provoking controversy with religious leaders but proving His authority by healing the man, confirming His power to forgive sins on earth.

outline.heading: Calling of Levi and Jesus’ Ministry to Sinners
outline.description: Jesus calls Levi, a tax collector, who immediately follows Him. Jesus explains His mission to call sinners to repentance, contrasting His approach with the religious leaders’ expectations.

outline.heading: Teaching on Fasting and Newness
outline.description: Jesus addresses questions about fasting, using the metaphors of new cloth on old garments and new wine in old bottles to illustrate the incompatibility of His new covenant with old religious practices.

application: Trust in Jesus’ word and obey His commands even when circumstances seem discouraging, as Peter did when casting the nets.
Recognize Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and seek His forgiveness with humility and faith.
Follow Jesus wholeheartedly, leaving behind old ways and priorities as the first disciples and Levi did.
Embrace the new life and teachings Jesus brings, being open to transformation rather than clinging to old religious traditions.

keyVerses.text: And so was also James, and John, the sons of Zebedee, which were partners with Simon. And Jesus said unto Simon, Fear not; from henceforth thou shalt catch men.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jesus’ call to discipleship and the mission to evangelize, transforming fishermen into fishers of men.

keyVerses.text: And when he saw their faith, he said unto him, Man, thy sins are forgiven thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ divine authority to forgive sins, a central claim of His ministry that challenged religious leaders.

keyVerses.text: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
keyVerses.significance: This succinctly states Jesus’ mission to bring salvation to sinners, emphasizing grace and the need for repentance.

keyVerses.text: And he spake also a parable unto them; No man putteth a piece of a new garment upon an old; if otherwise, then both the new maketh a rent, and the piece that was taken out of the new agreeth not with the old.
keyVerses.significance: This parable teaches about the incompatibility of Jesus’ new covenant with old religious systems, calling for spiritual renewal.
